timeline.event: Levelling Up and Regeneration Act receives Royal Assent
timeline.detail: Gives Secretary of State powers to create unitary authorities without local consent
English Devolution White Paper signals push for reorganisation
Five proposals submitted by Lancashire councils ahead of deadline
Framework for Mayoral Strategic Authorities and mandatory unitarisation
7-week consultation on 5 proposals for restructuring Lancashire's 15 councils
Secretary of State announces chosen boundary model
Voters elect councillors for new unitary authorities
New unitary authorities go live, all 15 current councils abolished

proposed_models.name: Two Unitaries
proposed_models.description: Divides Lancashire broadly along the River Ribble into North and South. LCC's preferred option — the only model where all authorities meet the government's 500,000 population threshold.

authorities.name: North Lancashire
authorities.notes: Historic Lancaster, Fylde Coast tourism, Preston as admin capital, rural Ribble Valley. Includes existing Blackpool unitary.

authorities.name: South Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire mill towns, commuter belt, Blackburn with Darwen unitary. Diverse mix of urban deprivation and affluent suburbs.

strengths: Only model where ALL authorities exceed 500K population threshold
Highest projected annual savings (£21.2M/year after 5 years)
Simplest governance structure — fewest boundaries to draw
weaknesses: Very large authorities — risk of remote decision-making
Burnley/Pendle grouped with Chorley/West Lancs despite no geographic or economic connection
Mixes highly deprived areas (Burnley, Blackburn) with affluent areas in same authority
80% of Burnley/Pendle survey respondents opposed merger with Blackburn with Darwen

proposed_models.name: Three Unitaries
proposed_models.submitted_by: Blackburn with Darwen, Fylde, Hyndburn, Rossendale and Wyre councils
proposed_models.description: Creates Coastal, Central and Pennine Lancashire, aligned with existing policing divisions and public service boundaries.

authorities.name: Coastal Lancashire
authorities.notes: Coastal strip plus Lancaster. Tourism economy, university city, retirement demographics. Just below 500K threshold.

authorities.name: Central Lancashire
authorities.notes: Preston City Deal area plus West Lancashire. Strong commuter flows, M6/M65 corridor hub.

authorities.name: Pennine Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire mill towns plus Blackburn unitary and rural Ribble Valley. Shared deprivation challenges and industrial heritage.

strengths: Aligns with existing policing divisions and NHS boundaries
Balances population reasonably across three authorities
Pennine Lancashire reflects genuine economic and cultural ties
weaknesses: Coastal Lancashire just misses 500K threshold (493,387)
West Lancashire has weak ties to Preston/Chorley — closer economic links to Merseyside
Higher transition costs than 2-unitary model (£35M vs £28.6M)
Lancaster geographically distant from Blackpool despite being in same authority

proposed_models.name: Four Unitaries
proposed_models.submitted_by: Chorley, Lancaster, Preston, Ribble Valley, South Ribble and West Lancashire councils
proposed_models.description: Creates North, Fylde Coast, Pennine and South Lancashire. Supported by 6 district councils — the broadest cross-party coalition.

authorities.name: North Lancashire
authorities.notes: Lancaster to Preston corridor via M6. Two university cities, rural Ribble Valley. Lancaster City Council formally voted for this option.

authorities.name: Fylde Coast
authorities.notes: Coastal tourism strip. Blackpool, Lytham St Annes, Fleetwood. Shared seaside economy but stark deprivation contrasts.

authorities.name: Pennine Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire mill towns plus Blackburn unitary. Only authority in this model meeting 500K threshold.

authorities.name: South Lancashire
authorities.notes: M6 commuter belt. Chorley, Leyland, Ormskirk/Skelmersdale. Strong transport links to Manchester and Liverpool.

strengths: Respects existing economic partnerships and commuter patterns
North Lancashire brings Preston + Lancaster together as twin poles
weaknesses: CCN analysis: would COST £11.5M MORE per year than current system
Three of four authorities below 500K threshold
Highest transition cost (£41.3M)
Splits adult/children's social care services four ways — PwC warned of increased costs
Fylde Coast at only 348K — smallest viable authority proposed

proposed_models.name: Four Unitaries (Alt)
proposed_models.description: Only proposal that splits existing districts — divides Wyre and Ribble Valley wards between different authorities. Creates a larger Western authority centred on Blackpool/Preston.

authorities.name: Western Lancashire
authorities.notes: Blackpool + Fylde + Preston + 16 western Wyre wards. Largest authority in this model. Splits Wyre along the river.

authorities.name: Southern Lancashire
authorities.notes: Same as Proposal 3's South Lancashire grouping.

authorities.name: Eastern Lancashire
authorities.notes: Pennine Lancashire + 17 southern Ribble Valley wards. Ribble Valley split between East and North.

authorities.name: Northern Lancashire
authorities.notes: Lancaster + 10 Ribble Valley wards + 8 eastern/northern Wyre wards. At 201K, smallest authority in any proposal.

strengths: Creates larger Western authority (475K) closer to threshold
Blackpool gains critical mass with Preston and Fylde
Keeps Blackpool's tourism economy in single authority
weaknesses: Only proposal requiring ward-level boundary changes — legally complex
Northern Lancashire at 201,508 is far below 500K threshold
Government says boundary changes need 'strong public services and financial sustainability related justification'
Splits Wyre and Ribble Valley communities — opposed by both councils
Same CCN cost projections as Proposal 3 (£11.5M/year additional cost)

proposed_models.name: Five Unitaries
proposed_models.description: Creates five community-focused unitaries. 80% of local survey respondents supported this model. Prioritises local identity and democratic accessibility over economies of scale.

authorities.name: East Lancashire
authorities.notes: Core East Lancashire partnership. Shared industrial heritage, deprivation challenges, and strong community identity.

authorities.name: Central Lancashire
authorities.notes: Blackburn unitary + Hyndburn + Ribble Valley. Mixes urban Blackburn/Accrington with rural Ribble Valley.

authorities.name: North Lancashire
authorities.notes: Lancaster university city + Wyre coast. M6 corridor link. Relatively affluent, aging demographics.

authorities.name: South Lancashire
authorities.notes: Same South Lancashire grouping as Proposals 3 and 4. M6 commuter belt.

authorities.name: West Lancashire
authorities.notes: Note: despite the different name, this is Blackpool + Fylde + Preston (not West Lancashire borough). Coastal tourism + Preston city.

strengths: Strongest local democratic support (80% of residents surveyed)
Smallest authorities — closest decision-making to communities
East Lancashire reflects genuine shared identity and partnerships
weaknesses: No authority meets 500K population threshold
CCN did not model 5-unitary costs, but extrapolation suggests significant additional annual costs
Government guidance explicitly prefers 500K+ populations
Five-way split of social care increases fragmentation and recruitment challenges
Smallest authorities (East Lancashire 272K, North Lancashire 264K) far below threshold

ai_doge_analysis.title: AI DOGE Assessment
ai_doge_analysis.subtitle: Independent analysis based on £12B+ in spending data across all 15 Lancashire councils

assessments.reasoning: The only model generating significant annual savings (£21.2M). Both authorities clear the 500K population bar. However, AI DOGE spending data shows that South Lancashire would combine councils with wildly different spending patterns — Burnley's per-head spend is 2.4x Chorley's. This creates serious service harmonisation risk. The financial case is clear; the governance case is weaker.

assessments.verdict: Best balance of savings and identity
assessments.reasoning: AI DOGE cross-council analysis shows Pennine Lancashire councils already share similar supplier bases, spending patterns, and deprivation profiles. Coastal Lancashire's just-below-threshold population (493K) is a political risk but not a dealbreaker — government has stated exceptions are possible. Modest savings (£6.4M) but lower disruption risk.

The six-council coalition represents the broadest democratic mandate, but the CCN analysis is damning: this model would cost £11.5M MORE per year than the current system. AI DOGE data shows Fylde Coast at 348K population would inherit Blackpool's £4.1B debt profile with the smallest tax base of any proposed authority — a financial time bomb.

Splitting Wyre and Ribble Valley at ward level creates legal complexity that no recent English LGR has attempted. Northern Lancashire at 201K would be England's smallest unitary by a significant margin. AI DOGE spending data shows the ward-level splits would create data discontinuities making financial tracking nearly impossible during transition.

The 80% resident support is compelling, but no authority meets the 500K threshold and the CCN pattern clearly shows that more unitaries = higher costs. AI DOGE analysis shows East Lancashire (272K) would have the highest per-capita spend of any proposed authority due to concentrated deprivation, while lacking the tax base to fund county-level services like adult social care. The government is very unlikely to approve this model.

ai_doge_analysis.recommendation: Based on AI DOGE's analysis of £12 billion in spending data across all 15 councils, the Three Unitary model (Proposal 2) offers the best balance of financial viability, geographic coherence, and respect for local identity. The Two Unitary model saves more money but creates authorities too large for meaningful democratic engagement. The Four and Five Unitary models fail the basic financial test — they would cost taxpayers more than the current system.

key_issues.title: LCC Debt Transfer
key_issues.description: Lancashire CC holds significant borrowing including the VeLTIP bond portfolio (£519M invested, ~£169M current value — a ~£350M paper loss). How this debt is distributed to successor authorities is the single biggest financial risk of reorganisation.

key_issues.title: Dedicated Schools Grant Deficit
key_issues.description: LCC carries a DSG deficit projected to reach £419.9M by 2028/29. This statutory obligation for SEND provision will transfer to successor authorities, potentially overwhelming smaller councils.

key_issues.title: Reserves Distribution
key_issues.description: Combined reserves across all 15 councils must be fairly divided. AI DOGE data shows stark disparities — some councils hold healthy unallocated reserves while others are nearly depleted. Earmarked reserves tied to specific obligations complicate distribution.

key_issues.title: Social Care Fragmentation
key_issues.description: PwC analysis for CCN specifically warned about the cost of splitting adult and children's social care into multiple smaller councils. LCC currently runs social care for 1.2M people — splitting this 4 or 5 ways risks service quality, recruitment challenges, and increased per-capita costs.

key_issues.title: Staff TUPE Transfer
key_issues.description: Approximately 30,000+ staff across all 15 councils will need TUPE transfer to successor authorities. Different pay scales, pension schemes, and terms must be harmonised — typically the most expensive part of reorganisation.

key_issues.title: IT System Consolidation
key_issues.description: 15 councils run different IT systems for revenues, planning, housing, and corporate services. LCC's Oracle Fusion implementation has been plagued with data breaches and payment errors. System consolidation typically costs £20-50M per new authority.
